ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO
INFILTRATION OF TRADE
UNION MOVEMENT BY
POLITICAL PARTIES


    1. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether he will consider setting up a Commission of Inquiry into the trade union movement with specific reference to infiltration thereof by political parties, whether registered or unregistered.

    The Prime Minister (Mr Lee Kuan Yew): Mr Speaker, Sir, I will certainly consider setting up a Commission of Inquiry. I think most Members will agree that the Member for Thomson rendered the country a great service by accidentally proposing a Commission of Inquiry for the Chinese Schools Examination Boycott, as a result of which Communists ---

    An hon. Member: The Member for Anson and not the Member for Thomson.

    The Prime Minister: The Member for Anson - I beg your pardon. The Member for Anson is still standing on the same side of the line.

    Sir, as a result of that Commission of Inquiry, a certain number of Communists and Communist united front

Column: 128

operators working in the guise of educationists and protectors of culture and language were exposed and discomfited. I agree with the Member that a similarly useful role can be played by a Commission of Inquiry in respect of Communist activities in the trade unions.

    There is, at the moment, another Commission pending at the request of the Singapore National Union of Journalists. It is to inquire into the improper manner in which the Singapore National Union of Journalists was exploited by certain Communist united front operators and into the manner in which their funds were misused for Communist front ends.

    I think the general investigation can be joined with this specific investigation which has been asked for. The question is to find when a High Court Judge will be free to undertake what will undoubtedly become a long, protracted and sometimes perhaps acrimonious proceedings. The Member will remember that the former Chief Justice retired in January this year and we are at the moment one Puisne Judge short. However, the Chief Justice has assured me that he will make a Judge available as soon as the Court's list makes it possible.

    Mr David Marshall (Anson): A supplementary question, Mr Speaker, Sir. The Prime Minister, in indicating that he accepts the suggestion for the appointment of this Commission, left it limited to the question of Communist subversion. I ask whether the Prime Minister did that by accident or whether it is intended in the spirit of the question to appoint a Commission to inquire into all political activities and all political infiltration of trade unions, whether registered political Parties or not - the "not", of course, being the Communists.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, the distinction between Communist operators and non-Communist infiltrators does not lie in their belonging to a registered or an unregistered society. Many of the Communist operators belong to a registered society, and one of the political Parties is adequately

Column: 129

represented in this Chamber. That is in the nature of things in Singapore. I take it that the point the Member for Anson wanted to make was - have I, in framing this reply, taken into consideration his other point, to investigate the activities of non-Communist political leaders in the trade unions. But hypothesi, if they are non-Communists, therefore it cannot he for subversive ends.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, the question is "setting up a Commission of Inquiry with specific reference to infiltration", and the aim is to free the working-class movement from its thraldom to political Parties. That would be the aim of such a Commission. My enquiry is: does the Prime Minister accept the position that the trade union movement should be free from slavery to any political Party, and that a Commission would help immensely in clarifying the position and in probably paving the way for legislation for their protection?

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, that opens up an entirely new aspect of the case. As I understand it, the Member for Anson is now thinking in terms of legislation to free the trade union movement from thraldom - is it thraldom? I have not got the Oxford Dictionary with me here, but I assume, by that, that the Member for Anson means that one is held enthralled by the other. If that is so and if the purpose is then to make recommendations for legislation so that no trade union can either subscribe to, belong to or pay subscriptions to a political Party, I am quite happy to consider that. But infiltration by non-Communists into trade unions and trade union committees is just like some businessmen infiltrating into direct directorships of companies. It goes on regularly. The same man, for instance, turns up in 20 different companies-Fraser & Neave, Malayan Breweries, Red Lion, etc. By sheer persistence and great skill in the management of committees, the same person appears over and over again in the directorship lists of many companies, thereby no doubt invoking a great deal of confidence amongst the

Column: 130

public and the consumers of the various commodities. So too with trade unionists. One becomes an adviser, a general affairs officer, and so on.

    I think the objection to these persons is not that they work in trade unions but that they should work for the purposes of the Communist Party in trade unions. [Interruption] No, Mr Speaker, Sir. Any other political beliefs by all means. I sympathise with the Member for Anson. Twice he has lost his Party whilst he is still in this Chamber. I can quite sympathise with his point of view that one should not work for any political Party at all. I think there is reason and logic behind that point of view after one has had the bitter experiences that he has had. Twice the painful business of bringing a political Party to fruition; both came into life; one assumed power and one looked like coming to power and ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. I think the Prime Minister is now wandering and inciting a debate. I do not think we should allow that at Question Time. Perhaps he will cut his answer short.

    The Prime Minister: Mr Speaker, Sir, I see no harm whatsoever in Members opposite working in trade unions provided they are not doing it for Communist ends. I see no reason at all why no Members on this side of the House should not slave for trade unions if they feel so inclined.

PUBLIC ASSISTANCE TO VICTIMS
OF VOLCANIC DISASTER IN BALI


    2. Mr David Marshall asked the Prime Minister whether Government will consider sponsoring an appeal for monetary contributions from Singapore residents to assist victims of the volcanic disaster in Bali.

    The Prime Minister: Sir, the Government has no objections to any monetary contributions from Singapore residents to assist the victims of the volcanic disaster in Bali. It is best, however, if such subscriptions were to be sponsored by private charitable organisations.

AMENDING LEGISLATION TO
COURTS ORDINANCE TO COMMIT TO PRISON PERSONS GUILTY
OF CONTEMPT AND MALICIOUS
DISTORTION OF COURT PROCEEDINGS


    3. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether he will consider introducing legislation to amend the Courts Ordinance to enable District Judges to commit persons to prison for contempt during proceedings, as well as persons guilty of malicious distortion of court proceedings through radio, rediffusion, television and press reporting.

    Mr K. M. Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, under the Criminal Procedure Code, the subordinate Courts have certain powers on acts of contempt committed in the presence of the Court. These powers are not as wide as those enjoyed by the High Court. This follows precedents in the United Kingdom where subordinate Courts do not enjoy the extensive powers of the High Court.

    It is the High Court which has general superintendence over the proceedings of inferior Courts not only to prevent them from exceeding their jurisdiction or otherwise acting contrary to the law, but also to prevent persons from interfering with the course of justice in such Courts.

    The power of the Superior Court to punish for contempt has been under critical examination in England, and it was considered that such wide power should not be given to the subordinate Courts.

    However, I agree with the Member for Anson that our circumstances are different and I would welcome concrete proposals from members of the Bar and the Bar Committee itself.

    Persons guilty of malicious distortion of court proceedings through radio, rediffusion, television and press reporting can be dealt with adequately under the present laws for contempt under the existing provisions of the law.

APPLICABILITY OF PRINCIPLE
OF "OMBUDSMAN" TO
SINGAPORE


    4. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law whether he would consider the report of Sir John Whyatt on "The Citizen and the Administration" and the legislation arising therefrom in New Zealand in the context of the possibility of the applicability of the principle of "Ombudsman" to Singapore.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, the report of Sir John Whyatt on "The Citizen and the Administration" and the legislation arising therefrom in New Zealand have been carefully considered, but the view of the Government is that it is premature to apply the principle of "Ombudsman" in Singapore.

    We have already in existence in Singapore departments that cover to a great extent the powers, sphere of operations, rights and duties of an Ombudsman. The Central Complaints Bureau can be referred to in any case where the citizen complains of maladministration or delays in the public service. The Bureau has already helped to create a better understanding and appreciation of the duties of the civil service in serving the needs of the public.

    The Disciplinary Proceedings Regulations have been framed so that Civil Service Disciplinary Boards comprise not only civil servants but also members of the public. This will ensure that all matters of discipline will be enquired into and dealt with without prejudice and with due regard to the public interest.

    The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau works independently of the police and is responsible to the Minister for Home Affairs and the State Advocate-General.

    There are some practical difficulties in the institution of Ombudsman which have not been completely solved even in Denmark where it has been in existence for about six years. One of these difficulties is the right of the Ombudsman to look into secret files of Ministers as well as State departments.

Column: 133

While the Whyatt Report recommends that the Parliamentary Commissioner should have security of tenure in the same way as the Auditor General in Great Britain, in New Zealand he holds office only for the duration of Parliament. In the context of British parliamentary government and the principle of ministerial responsibility, it is difficult to demarcate the extent of the powers of the Ombudsman.

    The Whyatt Report has been criticised in Great Britain and its recommendations have not yet been adopted by the British Government.

    The position will, however, be kept under review. Last year, a legal officer made a special study of the system of Ombudsman in the Scandinavian countries. While the Government feels that it is better to allow existing institutions in Singapore to develop both by experience and activities, a close study will continue to be made of the experiments in other countries.

LEGISLATION TO LIMIT POWER
OF DISPOSAL OF ASSETS BY WILL


    5. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Health and Law when he anticipates being in a position to introduce legislation to limit the power of disposal of assets by will.

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, it will be in the very near future. The Inheritance Family Provisions Bill is in draft and has been referred to the Singapore Bar Committee who have indicated their agreement.

    Mr David Marshall: Mr Speaker, Sir, in view of the fact that an almost identical reply was given more than a year ago, can we hope that it will be introduced next June at the next sitting of this Assembly?

    Mr Byrne: Mr Speaker, Sir, everybody knows how harassed we were, but we have plenty of time this Session and it is hoped we will introduce this Bill, as well as the Intestate Succession Bill which has also being cleared by the Bar Committee, this Session.

DETAINEES UNDER P.P.S.O. IN
CENTRAL POLICE STATION
LOCK-UPS


    6. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether any detainees under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance are detained in the Central Police Station lock-ups, what is the longest period any detainee has been in such lock-up, and whether conditions in such lock-ups are subject to scrutiny by visiting justices or other non-police bodies.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, a number of persons detained under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance are at present held at the Central Police Station lock-up for interrogation purposes. The longest period during which any detainee has been held at the Central Police Station lock-up is since the time when the first batch of persons were arrested on 2nd February, 1963. The conditions at the Central Police Station lock-up are subject to inspection by a Board of Inspection consisting of the Solicitor-General and the Permanent Secretary, Ministry of Home Affairs.

    Mr David Marshall: Am I to understand, Sir, that some of them have been in this lock-up for more than two months? And since I am on my feet, if I might ask a second supplementary question? Would the Minister consider the suggestion of Amnesty International made to the Prime Minister that the Red Cross be given permission to investigate conditions?

    The Prime Minister: May I reply?

    Mr Speaker: No. It is Question Time. Mr Ong Pang Boon.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: There is no objection to inspection by the Red Cross. As I have said just now, some of them have been in detention at the Central Police Station lock-up since 2nd February.

DETAINEES UNDER P.P.S.O.
(Serving of Detention Orders and access to legal representatives)


    7. Dr Lee Siew Choh asked the Minister for Home Affairs when, where and how were detention orders served on detainees under the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance; and when were legal representatives permitted to see them.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker. Sir. Detention Orders were served on detainees within 16 days of their arrest in accordance with the provisions of the Preservation of Public Security Ordinance, 1955. In most cases, the Orders were served on them whilst they were in custody. Legal representatives were allowed to see the detainees immediately after the Statement of Grounds for the detention were served on them.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Only two days ago, the Minister said that legal counsel were allowed to see the detainees after one month. How does this tally with what he has said?

    Mr Speaker: The Minister would perhaps like to refer to his reply? It is at page 32 of the Hansard of 5th April, 1963.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, there is nothing inconsistent, if the Member looks up the provisions of the P.P.S.O., he will find that the Statement of Grounds will he served on the detainees within 14 days of the making of the Detention Order. And if he totals up the number of days, he will find that the period comes to about a month.

TOTAL NUMBER OF REGISTERED
UNEMPLOYED AND PUBLIC ASSISTANCE
PAID OUT IN FEBRUARY 1963


    10. Mr David Marshall asked the Minister for Labour (a) what was the total number of registered unemployed on the 28th February, 1963; (b) what was the number of such unemployed receiving public assistance; and (c) what was the sum of public assistance disbursed for the month of February 1963.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Labour (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply.

    The total number of persons actively seeking employment assistance on the 28th February, 1963, was 33,673 persons. It cannot be said that all the

Column: 137

33,673 registrants are unemployed. There are persons who have registered themselves at the Employment Exchange in the hope of getting better employment elsewhere.

    The total number of persons on the Employment Register receiving public assistance on 28th February, 1963, was 7,851.

    The answer to the last part of the question is that the total amount of public assistance disbursements for February 1963 to 24,666 cases was $780,621.20.

    Mr David Marshall: Do I understand that there were 24,000 cases for public assistance of unemployed in the month of February last?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: The unemployment cases who registered for public assistance on 28th February, 1963, was 7,851.

    Mr David Marshall: What is the figure of 24,000 given then?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: That is the total number of cases that are registered with the Welfare Department for public assistance. It is the total number of cases.

    Mr David Marshall: May I have information as to whether, in fact, there are persons registered for employment who are known to be employed? That is to say, there is no register of unemployed. But there is a register where people are taken in who are both employed and unemployed. Is that the position?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no separate registration. We have to accept everyone who wants to register with the Employment Exchange and who claims that he is unemployed, because there is no way of checking whether he is employed or not.

    Mr David Marshall: In that case, is it fair then to say that the 33,673 claimed to be unemployed?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, we must not confuse. When we refer to the public assistance figures, it is the number of cases. A head of family

Column: 138

may be unemployed and he registers himself for public assistance. So the number of 7,851 represents the number of cases that are classified as unemployed for public assistance.

    Mr David Marshall: Forgive me, Mr Speaker. I have the figures, and it is the gentleman who is confused. I am referring to the figure of 33,673 registered on 28th February, 1963. Are those the people who claimed that they were unemployed? 33,673?

    Mr Wee Toon Boon: Sir, that is so.

COMMISSION OF INQUIRY INTO
CHINESE SECONDARY FOUR
EXAMINATION BOYCOTT
(Expenditure and legal fees involved)


    11. Dr Lee Siew Choh asked the Minister for Education what expenditure was involved in the Commission of Inquiry into the Chinese Secondary Four Examination Boycott in November/December 1961; how many legal representatives were engaged by the Government, on whose behalf were they engaged and from which legal firms; and what amount of legal fees was paid in each case.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Lee Khoon Choy) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply. The expenditure to date for the Commission of Inquiry into the Government Secondary Four (Chinese) Examination Boycott in 1961 is $18,026.04.

    Only one legal representative was engaged by the Government. This legal representative was engaged as Counsel for the Minister for Education. The solicitor concerned is attached to the legal firm of solicitors, Messrs. Lee and Lee. He was paid token fees on the basis of assigned Assize cases, i.e. token fees intended to defray a lawyer of his transport and out-of-pocket expenses when he undertakes the duty to defend an accused charged with murder at the request of the Court.

    The total amount of legal fees paid to date covering 79 sittings of the Commission amounted to $9,675.

TRANSPORT DIFFICULTY FOR
SCHOOL CHILDREN ON PULAU
BRANI AND PULAU BLAKANG MATI


    12. Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware that children living on Pulau Brani and Pulau Blakang Mati and schooling in Singapore are having transport difficulty in going to and from Singapore; whether he has received petitions from the parents of those school-children; and whether he will make a statement on the matter.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have been asked to reply. The Minister is aware of the transport difficulties encountered by children living on islands who have to attend schools in Singapore. In the case of Pulau Brani and Pulau Blakang Mati, there are in existence 3 primary schools which cater for nearly 750 pupils. The problems of daily transport across the seas affect about 120 pupils only.

    On 21st February, 1963, a petition was received purporting to have been signed by 72 residents of Kampong Pulau Blakang Mati.

Column: 140



    The Ministry has endeavoured to solve the problem by seeking the co-operation of the War Department by adjusting the time-tables of their ferry services. Likewise, the assistance of the Master Attendant's Department and even that of the Straits Trading Company were sought. However, the commitments of these bodies have limited their ability to provide all the transport required for pupils and at times convenient for pupils. Therefore, the Ministry can Only do its best to alleviate the situation by resorting to the following measures:-

    (a) Increasing the awards for Island bursaries valued at $600 per annum from 14 in 1961 to 21 in 1962.

    (b) Initiating a new scheme of transport bursaries for Island pupils attending secondary schools in Singapore valued at $360 per annum. Circulars to this effect were issued to principals on 15th March, 1963, and applications are being processed. The vote approved by Treasury for 1963 is $49,800.

    (c) To build more rural type schools on islands if and when demands and availability of site justify such building. As in the case of Pulau Blakang Mati, which will be answered separately as a result of another question raised hereafter.

    Mr David Marshall: A supplementary, Sir. Can we have any indication of the number of these transport bursaries that it is anticipated will be awarded?

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is difficult to predict the number of applications.

    Mr David Marshall: For how many people?

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: It depends on the number of applications.

MALAY SCHOOL AT PULAU BLAKANG MATI


    13. Inche Ahmad Jabri Bin Mohammad Akib asked the Minister for Education when will a Malay School at Pulau Blakang Mati be built.

ADULT EDUCATION BOARD -
FLOWER-ARRANGEMENT AND
PHOTOGRAPHY CLASSES
(Request for Statement)


    14. Mr Leong Keng Seng asked the Minister for Education whether he is aware that flower-arrangement and photography classes are being conducted

Column: 142

by the Adult Education Board; how many students are there in each type of classes; how many teachers are teaching in these classes; what is the cost of conducting each of these classes; and whether he will make a statement as to the need for such classes.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister is, of course, aware that flower-arrangement and photography courses are being conducted by the Adult Education Board. In fact, the Minister opened the first exhibition of the works of the Adult Education Board at the Victoria Memorial Hall on 8th March, 1963.

    A total of 14 classes on flower arrangement with 323 students have been organised since March 1962. There are two part-time instructors for these courses, one conducted in English and the other in Mandarin.

    16 courses on photography have been organised since October 1961, and 608 students have gone through these courses. Two part-time instructors are engaged in these courses, one for the English section and the other for the Chinese section.

    All these classes are conducted on a self-supporting basis.

    Courses on photography and flower-arrangement are primarily recreational courses which are intended to assist members of the public to make use of their leisure hours profitably. This is an important aspect of adult education especially in our society today, where trade unions have been successful in getting shorter working hours, thereby increasing the leisure hours of our workers. Some of the students of the photography courses have also been able to secure employment on the strength of the tuition given by the Board in its photography courses.

    Mr Low Por Tuck (Havelock): Sir, how many of the students of the flower-arrangement classes are workers?

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: Most of them are workers, Sir.

ADJOURNMENT TO A LATER DAY MOTION


3.10 p.m.

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That at its rising on Tuesday, the 9th April, 1963, this Assembly do stand adjourned to the 7th of June, 1963.

    Mr Speaker, the Prime Minister already explained to the House on Friday why this Assembly cannot sit on the 10th and 11th of this week. At some later stage this afternoon I will sound the mood of this House as to whether it is desirable or not to continue today's sitting to midnight.
